text: lying closed on an old-fashioned wooden teaching lectern. We are ANGLED DOWN so all we can see is a piece of the mec rese and the TITLE of the book (also the title of our movie)...

The book miraculously opens by itself and, as a nostalgic version of "SCHOOL DAYS" PLAYS OVER, the pages quickly unfold the back story of Dick and Jane and the names and titles of the people who make this movie. The whole style of the opening should be a kind of kiddy-version of those "Book Openings'' to old MGM movies. Like this... MUSIC AND TITLES CONTINUE. We blow open to the first page where the story begins. This page is labeled, "DICK" at the bottom and the picture on the page is of a young boy of about ten sitting under a tree reading "IVANHOE." In the background is a large, comfortable house. (NOTE: All the pictures in the book are in that romanticized and nai style unique to the Dick and Jane Series. But we shall use the real childhood photos of our stars, Jane Fonda an George Segal.) Another page turns and we SEE a picture of Dick's father, a rugged but gentle, distinguished but earthy, fun but serious, neat but casual guy, standing on the front porch of the house holding a football and shouting to his son, Dick, who has. dropped his book and is looking eagerly at his father. Beneath the picture are these words... *
Another page blows open. The ball has been thrown and Dick is running after it. Caption...
Another page turns and we SEE Dick, now in a high school football uniform and helmet, running to catch a pass. This picture is captioned... .

as we SEE DICK running through various stages of his life years 15 through 19. He is in constant motion; running to classes, delivering newspapers, running for class office, running in every known.sporting activity, running with hi friends after a group of giggling girls. Beneath all this is the caption... "RUN, DICK; RUN.

as another page blows open and we SEE a picture of a darl little girl in pigtails sitting on her pretty bed. Outsid her window stands a magnolia tree complete with a chirpin robin. | The girl is reading "IVANHOE." This picture is abeled...

A page turns and the next picture is of Jane's mother com in the room with a big wrapped present as Jane's eyes lig up. Jane's mother is an even more wholesome-looking perso than Dick's father. This picture is captioned... =
JANE opens the gift her MOTHER has given her.. It's a pla tea set. Jane's Mother begins showing her how to set up the tea things on the bed, shoving the book aside. (CONTINUED)
Have fun, Jane. Play and have fun.

briefly fleshing out Jane's junior high and high school years...which seem to be one long whirl of fun. We SEE Jane dancing with a boy, trying to study in a class but succumbing to the flirting of a boy behind her, jumping up in a cheer-leader costume (great legs), taking a home- class, sleeping at a slumber party that is suddenly attac by a group of boys, etc. UNDER THESE DISSOLVES the same legend remains constant... "PLAY, JANE, PLAY.
Many pages blow by as MUSIC AND TITLES CONTINUE. The miraculous breeze stops at a page titled:

ABOVE THIS TITLE is an idealized picture of a college (imposing and friendly). Eager students approach this citadel of learning from different paths. Easily discern- ible are Dick and Jane, coming from different directions.

Dick's college life. _We SEE him in various classes, most of them centering on aerospace and related mathematical subjects. In the brief snatches of non-classroom life (playing ball, trying out for a play), he seems happier. BENEATH all this ACTION:

head_text.subj: GRADES AND GET A GOOD JOB."

text: Pretty much the same as Dick, only her classes are more liberal-artsy and she seems to have a much easier time of it, getting good grades, helping others study, but goofing off really more than Dick and going out with a lot of different boys.
This picture shows a very 1950's collegiate Dick and Jane bumping into each other backstage at an auditorium. The - caption reads:

Pages blow, finally fall open on an evening scene of a beautiful lake with two big trees framing both sides of the peaceful moonlit scene. A 1956 Ford is parked at a perfect vista spot. This is a PUZZLE PAGE and the trees are drawn in such a way that it's possible to image faces in them. This picture is captioned:
++.a police car ENTERS the SCENE and pulls up next to the Ford. A cop shines his flashlight down into the back seat on Dick and Jane in the semi-sexual position of the 50's. A new caption appears:
FREEZE FRAME. Picture becomes:
Pages flip and fall open on a very idealized and romanti- (CONTINUED)
G cized shot of Dick and Jane as bride and groom. Caption , "DICK AND JANE GET MARRIED.
Another page blows over and we SEE a drawing of a kindly
old doctor winking at Jane as she hands him a piece of wedding cake at the party.
More pages blow quickly, we SEE a drawing of Dick in a business suit approaching a large aerospace corporation, / "DIXON AIRCRAFT." This page is captioned: . "DICK GETS A FINE JOB.
A page blows over and we SEE a drawing of Jane standing i | a brand new living room with an apron on, feeding a bab "JANE GETS A FINE JOB.
, S More pages flip to a portrait of an adorable little b ; and white puppy. This picture is labeled: , "Spot" ;

| +»Dick, Jane, their little baby (in an outdoor playpen) and Spot laughing merrily in front of a brand new house. | '.. Dick is rolling a ball and Spot is stumbling after baby Billy laughs happily. |
Run, Spot, run. See, Billy? See Spot run? Dick and Jane hug each other. We FREEZE FRAME on the tender tableaux.
The page blows over to a page with a picture of just cred
(CONTINUED)
cards...BANKAMERICARD, AMERICAN EXPRESS, TEXACO, etc. The caption is:
The page blows over and we SEE another drawing of "DIXON AIRCRAFT.'" The storybook colors have turned dark, the building looks ominous and forbidding. Caption... "UNTIL OCTOBER 24th, 1975'"
As a Lincoln pulls in, we can't help noticing the vast ga between cars, the lot somewhat less than half-filled.
Dick Harper, young, attractive, assured, carrying a soft leather attache case, emerges from car, strides toward ‘ building. Suddenly, he stops short.

In those spaces, where "Reserved" places are marked for executives, he sees a Mexican worker lazily painting out a name. Fresh white paint already obliterates two other names. The Mexican worker's name, incidently, is RAOUL. ©

Some 50 work desks, but only 15 to 20 functioning, the ot unattended, At functioning desks, black girls decked out white surgical costumes, large magnifying glasses before are working on tiny transistors. As Dick and Roger, another V.P., pass, en route.to elevat
Christ, the body count is getting heavy around here.
Half of accounting was wiped out this morning. Structural design is taking heavy casualties. As they reach the elevator door, and it opens, drunken singing is heard from within.
Bob...Oh, God...
Revealing Bob, clearly drunk, emerging from elevator, bei supported by yet another V.P., Marty.
Good luck. I've just been asked to cut back my division by forty per cent. I feel like the grim reaper. :

We.all feel the same’ way, but what are you going to do? After the last quarter -- BOB (interrupting) The company's on its ass. The whole aerospace industry is on its ass. Son of a bitch. I need another drink.
As ghey wander off and elevator doors shut on a perturbed Dic

location: DIXON OUTER OFFICE OF CHARLES SANFORD

text: Secretary sadly looks up as Dick strides past, into offic of Gharlie Sanford, Corporate Vice-President of Dixon Air Craft.

Dick comes in to discover Sanford sitting on a leather co with his coat off, his feet propped up on coffee table, a drink in hand. Charlie is a big athletic looking man, fif with a lot of silver hair. His walls are lined with frame signed photographs of astronauts, military brass, cabinet ministers. :
Dick...Sit down and pour yourself a drink.
Thanks, Charlie. Dick pours himself a drink.
This business stinks. You know that?
Well...

To know the feeling that you've been a part of the team that tied the lace on the shoe that took that giant step for mankind. You don't get that from building a goddamn missile. It stinks. It used to be the most exciting business in the world, and now it stinks on ice.
It's been a rough year.
It stinks.
I guess it does stink.
It stinks on ice,
On ice, Right.
What's all this crap? He's referring to Dick's stack of papers, charts, etc.
It's my plan to re-organize my department. I figure... CHARLIE (interrupting) One small step. One giant step for mankind...
Oh I wouldn't say that. But it's not a bad plan, I ----
You know who made that step possible? We did. You and me - and Bob Kane and Marty Fields. We put Neil and whats-his-name on the fucking moon and then they gave us the shaft. It stinks.
On ice.
Goddamn right it does. Charlie finishes his drink, pours himself another.
How's you drink? » DICK Fine, CHARLIE . Well...What do you say we talk , turkey?
In response, Dick begins to arrange his papers in front o
- I've tried to think of cutting back in terms of cost rather than...
Dick... ¢ \ (pause)
CONTINUED: . 1o.
Charlie...?
Dick, I've always felt you were a guy I didn't have to bullshit.
I'm glad to hear that.
In this job you have to bullshit a lot of guys, give 'em the old stroke...you know...But I've always felt I could level with you. You know what I mean?
Sure.
Can I level with you?
_ Sure.
I mean really level?
..,@harlie, you can tell me anything.
You're fired. Charlie breaks up. Dick laughs too, uneasily.
I never once said it straight out like that. DICK (laughing) . Practice makes perfect. But Charlie is suddenly depressed.
No, I shouldn't have done that. It's just that I'm sick of all the bullshit. I'm sorry. I shouldn't have...
Wait a minute... you're serious? CHARLIE (hurt) Would I kid a pal?
No jokes, Charlie. You're really firing me? Charlie tries to salvage a little of his corporate manner
I don't have to tell you. this has been a rough year for us...

But I haven't done a bad job. » CHARLIE You've done a helluva job. Don't let anybody tell you different. Shit, you know how I feel about you and Jane. ‘ DICK . Then why me? Why not Marty or Bob? My division's out-performed both of theirs. CHARLIE (vague) Seniority...I think that's what it was alee vores yyseniority. I'm sure that's what it was. Yeah...
I can't believe it. The high point of Charlie's drunk has faded and now he is verging on the nod.

Listen, Dick, do you mind if we don't go into all this crap now? Frankly, I'ma little looped and... I've got blood on my hands...a lot of blood... . Cunningly, he now feigns sleep. Dick just stands there for a moment, glaring at him, uncertain. Finally, he gathers his papers and leaves.
Cosy Dick emerges into secretary's office. He pays no att } until she stops him. ° ELEANOR . Mr. Harper...I just want to say that I'm very sorry you're leaving us.
Thank you.
Did Mr. Sanford tell you about the car?
) What car? .
The company car you've been using. You can retain the use of it for two weeks.

Isn't that thoughtful? ELEANOR (obsequious smile) And we will continue to pay your membership in the country club until the end of the quarter, but we must have your company credit cards now, please. A beat; even as she holds out her hand.
Damn it, they're in my other suit. I'll bring them round tomorrow. . Then, as he turns to go, she lapses automatically into cheery Californese.
Oh, and have a nice day.

head_text.subj: EXT. DIXON AIRCRAFT PARKING LOT DAY

text: Dick, pulling out angrily, all but stripping the gears of his Lincoln.
(> Driving, mutters to himself.
Holiday Inn by roadside,
FAVORING HOLIDAY INN Marquee, which reads: “HAPPY BIRTHDAY WANDA WUD U BELIEVE (sic)
As Dick pulls into lot, gets out of his car, starts towar Inn. .

Dark, gloomy. Maybe eight or nine men and women drinking morosely at tables. The BARTENDER, a big, bronzed Indian, long greasy black hair, headband, is coping with a drunke salesman as Dick sits down at the bar, . DRUNK (to bartender) Screw that. You just tell me where it says in the Bible -- and I want chapter and verse, man -- that the Indians are entitled to land claims settlements? DICK . A J & B on the rocks, please. Make it a double.
Did your boys invent the electric light? Or the jet engine? Shit; you still hadn't discovered the fucking wheel when we landed here.
Wait. When Dick Harper drinks, everybody drinks, The bartender remains impassive.
No shit? (CONTINUED)
(with a sweeping gesture) Drinks on the house.
Bartender taking orders, filling glasses.
Everybody raisingafull glass to their benefactor, big Dick Harper, which he graciously acknowledges, raising his own glass.
Bartender slaps down bill, which Dick promptly covers wit his company credit card. : :
We PAN with bartender as he goes to phone, dials, reads o -eredit card number, repeats it, nods, hangs up, returns confront a still beaming munificent Dick.
It's no good, oo, DICK - What! TSS BARTENDER . Your credit's been cancelled,
Those sons of bitches.
That'll be twenty-eight sixty.
Twenty-eight sixty!
Hey, ask him to throw Manhattan Island in with the deal, (CONTINUED)
As he explodes with laughter at his own foul joke, Dick, seething, digs into his pockets for the cash.
Indignant Dick striding toward his Lincoln,
Edging out, Dick reverses, inadvertently running into parking lot concrete bumper guard,
cu DICK Suddenly, an evil smile. -
SOUND: Grinding gears, shattering glass, as a car is bein pounded against concrete 0.S. . We see a stunned old man...a lady in curlers,,.two small watching something...utterly baffled.
Dick finally pulling out, his big smile manic, waving at small audience, from his battered Lincoln, as he pulls triumphantly into traffic. curt TO:

Fairly new, fairly large, Mediterranean style house. Pandemonium in garden, however, Excavator excavating, concrete being mixed, tiles being moved, plants being emb +.+.1l year old BILLY Harper, other kids, playing footbal through the confusion and racket...and overseeing all thi (CONTINUED)

activity, the big, muscular, barechested MR. GOLDONI. Han from Goldoni's bull-neck, a pendant with an astrological (Aquarius), as well as a whistle on a chain. ...as Dick pulls up in his freshly battered Lincoln and walks across the lawn, through din, he is confronted by . the menacing Goldoni.
Mr. Harper! Dick ignores him.
(blocking his path) Oh, Mr. Harper,
(shouting to make himself heard) What is it? :
Congratulations. Your second payment on the pool is due today. (even as he thrusts a statement at him) A check would be most convenient.
From the window, ESPERANZA, the maid, sees the two men ‘s gesticulating. Wiping her hands on a towel. ESPERANZA = (calling urgently) Senora Harper! Senora Harper!
Dick and Goldoni
But your wife said --- ~N As Jane, on the trot, comes within earshot. (CONTINUED)
DICK (shouting back) I don't give a shit what my wife said,
JANE (aghast) Oh, Dick... DICK (shouting) I've just been fired,
Startled

Goldoni reaches for his whistle and blows on it shrilly.. once, twice... PANNING over the wreck of the garden as everything comes to an abrupt halt: the cement mixer, the tile-layers, the excavator, Everything. A sudden menacing silence enhanced by Goldoni's big intimidating presence.
What did you say? ; as DICK (to Jane) Hee Tell him what you said,
No. You. ‘ Jane is the first to recover,
He said he was tired, Goldoni. shakes his head, he grins, admiring her cool, bu he is not to be conned,
Mr, Harper you were canned today.
Yeah.
As Billy comes running up.
Hey, Dad, what did you do to your car?
Not now, Billy. A dry tense pause, as Dick braces himself, fists clenched and Goldoni, all belligerence, reflects suddenly, without warning, driving a finger into a terrified Dick.
What's your sign?
The Aquarian sign Goldoni wears. DICK (chancing it) Aquarius.
Oh, you poor prick, I knew it. He walks away, holding his head, lips pursed, and returns despairing.
As of yesterday, our Third House is empty. Dick whistles in amazement.
It's a real ball-crusher, Jupiter has just entered our Seventh House and --- oh, shit, you might as well know --- Mars is in direct juxtaposition to Saturn.

Oh, my God, no. As Goldoni curses his luck --- Dick's luck --- roundly in GOLDONI . It's a bad time for us, a real bummer. I'll give you until next Wednesday. And turning away from them, he blows on his whistle again once, twice, and the men resume work. CUT To:
Q Cozy, middle-class, Snoopy and other stuffed animals. T everywhere. As Jane tucks him in, switches on night light and slips out the door,

head_text.subj: EXT, FRONT DICK AND JANE'S HOUSE

text: We note, in passing, a 17 foot boat on a trailer in adjoi driveway. We also note that all the gardens we can see, including Dick and Jane's, are well-lit, spotlights conce in shrubbery. SOUND: A shrill, pulsating police siren approaching --- seemingly upon them --- then fading into the night.

head_text.subj: EXT, REAR DICK AND JANE'S HOUSE

text: Dick and Jane are by the hold partially dug for their lon awaited swimming pool. Excavating equipment alongside, al stacks of tiles, etc. A child's toys also on seat of the excavator ---smiling---as she watches a somewhat looped D . trying stunts on Billy's skateboard, Finally, he stroll : G over to her, joining her at poolside’, Jane refills b their glasses with wine,
I can't believe it, Charlie fired you.
Charlie fired me.
That son of a bitch. After all the years of bottom-pinching I took from him.
Dick maintains a morose silence. JANE (contin) The hell with them. You'll get a better job. No answer,
Won't you? (CONTINUED)
You're dam right I will. A beat; Jane staring at pool. JANE (meekly) What are we going to do about paying for the pool?
Darling, there is nothing to worry about. But Jane is now prepared to make real sacrifices.
Look, we won't heat it. Not until you get another job.

And what will the neighbors say if .they don't see steam rising off our pool on chilly nights/ fas he gropes for her, kissing her neck) Dick Harper's a loser! JANE (responding to his advances) Screw the neighbors. We're going to start making some real economies around here, I'm going to give up my tennis lessons, No more French wines at home. And I'm going to start canning things, just like my mother. ‘DICK (his advances growing more heated) I do appreciate your pioneering spirit, Calamity, and now if you'd care to mosey upstairs with me there's something in my sleeping bag I'd like to show you. JANE (kissing him) Shoot. What could that be?
Well, it's good for lumbago, athlete's foot, headache,..and guaranteed to melt your little ole panty straps.
You are talkin' dirty now! As they embrace,

location: DICK AND JANE'S HOUSE, ESPERANZA'S ROOM

text: Esperanza gathers up her large, overstuffed cardboard suitcase, bound with cord.
As a taxi driver takes Esperanza's suitcase, she walks to where Billy is trying to flip a basketball into net overh doors, Baffled, he allows himself to be hugged and kissed departing maid. :
Across the street, the Bradleys have just pulled up, gett 21.
of their car, He's a fat fellow, spilling over his Bermud
Esperanza getting into taxi.
The Harper's maid is leaving!
What? MRS. BRADLEY (shoving him) Hurry! Damn you! She may not have another job yet.
Bounding Bradley, in his Bermudas, succeeds in stopping t  54 55. 56.
Omitted

Dick, who has obviously been on the phone for hours, nods inta receiver, as we HEAR a click on the other end of the and he x-s another name off a list on the pad before him. FAVORING pad, we see that it is a list of all the country airplane manufacturing firms, the last name and hope now

As Billy spills into the room, Dick, still holding ‘dead! parodies the day,'s defeats for his son, DICK (into 'dead' phone) Hello, Harry, Long time no see, How goes the battle? Yeah, sure. Tell me, anything available at Lockheed? Yeah, pink slips. The girls in the secretarial pool. Ho, ho, ho. Billy looks on uncertainly as Dick hangs up phone.
Things are that tough, Dad?
It's not just that I'm unemployable --- I also seem to be obsolete! ’ Dick sees his son's growing alarm, decides to make light
Why don't you get a newspaper route, kid? Eleven years old and. still sponging off the old man. As he dives at him and the two of them begin to wrestle o the floor. cur To:
Chaos. Steam, steam everywhere. Boiling burning peaches. jars. Peelings. A totally undone, sweaty Jane, attempting getting everything wrong. CUT To:

PANNING over Billy, Jane, Dick, eating Hamburger Helper l not a word being said. Only sounds we hear that of cutler plates. Finally. JANE (obviously trying to cheer him up) Maybe your Third House is still empty.
That was last month, dear. Tomorrow Dick Harper puts his fabled shoulder to the wheel once more. JANE (overjoyed) You've found a job! DICK. Yeah,
. Doing what?
Let's just say I'm embarking on a second career, and leave it at that, shall we?

It's a large studio, and we PAN over rapt ‘students a dra sketching a figure as yet unseen, and the only sound we h scratching of charcoal pencils. PANNING over intent faces sketches, until, coming full circle, we come upon the mod reduced to a bikini, and striking a Thinker's pose for th
A "bartender needed" ad being circled with ballpoint.
Dick, clutching newspaper, entering what turns out to be topless (or bunnied) bar/restaurant.

PANNING over serving waitresses, the men at tables, as we dressed Dick finds himself, for the first time in his lif in a topless bar..,TRACKING with him to proprietor who si at cash register, In the enveloping din, we don't hear th conversation, but we see Dick point out Bartender Wanted to proprietor, who grins and slaps his cheek with amazeme
You crazy, man? The only require- ment for a bartender in this joint ~ is knockers. Shit, you couldn't . even bluff your way into a training bra. . -

head_text.subj: PAGE FROM DICK AND JANE STORYBOOK, TITLE READS

text: A large sullen mob has gathered outside the Department of Human Resources, We PICK UP Dick and Jane in her car as they stop at the curb. .
Jane is behind the wheel. Dick wears a suit and tie and a forlorn look. ‘“
You'd think you were committing a crime. Lots of people collect unemployment. | (CONTINUED)
It just seems there's no point in going through all this when I'm having lunch.with Jim Weeks at Northrop next week, He says that things are about to break over there.
Dick, my darling, you've been without work for three months now. We are in no position to be turning up our noses at ninety-five dollars week tax-free.

I've worked for every dime I've ever made in my life. Nobody ever gave me anything. JANE / . Nobody's giving you anything now. You have to work to collect unemployment. It's’ like insurance. (as she bends over to kiss him)
DICK (sullen) See you later,
I'd wait, you know, but I've got to pick up Billy.
I know.

Dick walks among the ranks of the unemployed. Apart from people who are there merely to get their money and beat i are the usual hangers on. Also, a small selection of real who make speeches, talk to themselves or sing. Dick is th person dressed in a suit and as a consequence he attracts He goes inside. :
Dick looking lost and a little panic stricken. An elderly woman standing in front of him turns around, bemused, and him up and down.
py You looking for a maid, honey. I can . iron like a dream. .
The truth is....

. (drifting away) Yeah, I know. You want somebody younger. Dick, moving away, embarrassed, finally sights the window marked INFORMATION. As he is about to join the long line leading up to it, he is accosted by a longhaired, bearded mustachioed Mexican (RAOUL)
You're Mr. Harper, aren't you? | Dixon Aircraft. .
Yes..?
I'm Raoul Esteban. Remember? I was with Dixon Maintenance Division. @ I used to do your office.
Sure... Raoul... How are you?
Raoul seems genuinely delighted to see Dick. Dick is un- comfortable. They shake hands. Great. Hey, what are you doin' here?.
‘No ready answer. o . & RAOUL : . They canned you too, huh?
Actually, it was more complicated-- “RAOUL
That company, man...They can all the guys who got ability. It's a bitch.
It sure is.
Is this your first time in here?
Damn right. I mean, yeah, it is.
Hey, man, you're in luck, I'm going to take care of you.
That's very decent of you.

Don't mention it. Mi casa, su casa, you know what I mean? First thing... You're in the wrong line. Information you stand in line two hours and all they tell you is to fill out one of these. He hands him a card, CUT To: |
A school for kids. Billy, and others his age, boys and gi with teeth braces, as instructor trots out, calling it a

Cars parked everywhere, Attractive, well-dressed young mo waiting, chattering, Jane among them. HOLD only long enou that we will remember the faces of some of these ladies, all the kids come charging out toward the cars. Among the

As Jane's car, Billy inside, pulls up in front of the hou gang of Goldoni's workmen busy repossessing the landscapi pool, incidentally, still half complete). Trees are pulle out of the ground, as are ferns and plants;.all done with care, Great gouges, however, are left in garden. Piles of etc, Jane gets out of car and speaks to one of the workme
n JANE FY Stop it! Stop!
This your house?
That's right. WORKMAN (yells) Pete...we got one of ‘em. Pete who is in charge today comes over to Jane. po PETE You got our notice, Mrs. Harper?
' Yes, and I sent you a check.
Bouncy, bouncy. That's naughty, Mrs.. Harper.
But I told you to put it throught again.
We did. That's. why we're here.
Look, just because the bank makes a mistake, is no reason to rip up my garden.
| . A check bounces once, that's a mistake. . Twice, we repossess.
Well, I'm going to call them right now. You just hold on. She starts into the house, Pete follows.
Where are you going?
I thought while you're calling I'd get the plants inside.
A . Get off my property before I call the ( 5 police.
Pete just stands there, clacking his tongue. . y ea | JANE (shouting) Right now. k PETE of C'mon, guys. Everybody back to the truck. : The workmen retire to the truck, Jane and Billy go into h

Meanwhile, Dick is discovering a new world. He and Raoul : having a beer and shooting a little pool. Some of the u office regulars are there, Mexican pop music in backgroun jukebox. Raoul, we see at once, is something of a pool sh Watching him shoot, Dick is charged with admiration. : :
Jane is on the phone. .
| But that's impossible! Are you | positive...? oo We HEAR Pete's voice coming through an electric bull horn ' the outside. . ie ee
Open the door, Mrs. Harper ---
Jane reacts in horror,
---or we'll huff, and we'll puff, and we'll blow your house down. JANE (into phone) Thank you. She hangs up and goes to door,
Pete is speaking through the electric bullhorn.

You are behind in your payments on your indoor-outdoor landscaping and your pool. We do not want your neighbors to know you are deadbeats, but we must repossess... Jane opens the front door. She looks utterly defeated.

Dick and Jane's garden, like all the others, illuminated, landscape in front of his house is all but totally denude Dick walks slowly to the front door, looking around him i disbelief -- pouf!--- suddenly all the lights in his gard well as any lights that were on in the house, are extingu
Even as Billy watches Hawaii Five-O or whatever, on TV, s the picture shrinks to the size of a postage stamp and go
Dick, entering, striking matches, as Billy comes running
You're just in time, Daddy. I think we blew a fuse.
I'm afraid not, Billy.
What's wrong, then?
Um, something of a misunderstanding ...between ourselves and the Department of Water and Power.

As Dick comes in, Jane is sitting in a chair wrapped in a menacing calm, flashlight in hand. For his benefit, she shines the flashlight on those places where plants, now repossessed, used to stand. Dick stumbles over to sideboa pours himself a small scotch, draining the bottle. The la
Are you going to tell me how bad things really are, or are we just going to . wait for the roof to fall on our heads?
SOUND: Scales.
A music stand before him, he is practicing by the light o Coleman Camp lamp.
SOUND: Flute. Scales again and again. Dick and Jane sit across the desk from each other. The candlelight is romantic, but on the desk, a very business file of papers, documents, etc.
Look, Jane, it isn't all that bad.
We have no income and no assets, | Dick. |
We have the house. |
We owe eighty seven thousand dollars on the house..,but never mind that for the moment. I see that you've left fifteen thousand dollars in your will to your sister.
Yeah..?
If you died tonight I'd owe her the - fifteen thousand, wouldn't I?
It would come out of the insurance,
Guess what, darling?
Don't tell me. I don't want to know.
There is no insurance, You've borrowed against it.
Look, this is ridiculous, I'm not going to die tonight. Dick Harper is in his prime.
Yes. Maybe,
_ The "maybe". scorches. Dick is suddenly outraged,
If Dr. Rabinovitch told you anything he didn't tell me after my last check- up, it is your duty to come clean. Right now. I want it straight from the shoulder, Jane is baffled.
What_on earth are you talking about?
My health. All I've got left. He assured me it was tennis elbow. (leaning close) Is it terminal, Jane? I demand to know.
JANE My There is absolutely nothing wrong with your health. But, Dick, you have been leading a whole secret life in the last few years, haven't you? Now he is really ready to blow his top.
You are looking at a faithful husband, Mrs. Harper. I haven't even been to see 'Deep Throat' yet.
I'm not talking about sex, I'm talking about money. Here I always thought of you as Dick Harper, mild-mannered husband-- DICK (insulted) Mild-mannered? Thank you.
